Line 37: Line 37:
Eugenius was dignified in demeanour, but inexperienced and vacillating in action and excitable in temper. Bitter in his hatred of [[heresy]], he nevertheless displayed great kindness to the poor. He laboured to reform the [[monasticism|monastic]] orders, especially the [[Franciscan]], and was never guilty of [[nepotism]]. Although austere in his private life, he was a sincere friend of [[art]] and learning, and in 1431 he re-established the [[university]] at Rome.
Eugenius was dignified in demeanour, but inexperienced and vacillating in action and excitable in temper. Bitter in his hatred of [[heresy]], he nevertheless displayed great kindness to the poor. He laboured to reform the [[monasticism|monastic]] orders, especially the [[Franciscan]], and was never guilty of [[nepotism]]. Although austere in his private life, he was a sincere friend of [[art]] and learning, and in 1431 he re-established the [[university]] at Rome.
